Legumes and its effects on breast cancer

  • This prospective study suggests that vegetable fiber intake may contribute to reduce breast cancer risk, in line with experimental mechanistic data.
    • Link to article
    • Citation:
        • PLoS ONE. Published 2013.
  • This study suggests that greater consumption of isoflavone-containing foods is associated with a reduced risk of endometrial cancer in this population of nonhysterectomized postmenopausal women.
    • Link to article
    • Citation:
        • JNCI Journal of the National Cancer Institute. Published 4 January 2012.
  • Associations of dietary patterns with breast cancer risk varied by menopausal and body mass index status, but there was little difference in associations between non-Hispanic white and Hispanic women.
    • Link to article
    • Citation:
        • The American journal of clinical nutrition. Published April 2008.
  • A ‘high-alcohol’ dietary pattern derived with RRR was associated with an increased breast cancer risk; no evidence of associations of other dietary patterns with breast cancer risk was observed in this study.
    • Link to article
    • Citation:
        • European journal of clinical nutrition. Published December 2014.
  • Our results suggest that high intake of total vegetables, certain fruits, milk, and eggs may reduce the risk of breast cancer, while high consumption of animal-source foods may increase risk. The dietary associations did not appear to vary by ER/PR status.
    • Link to article
    • Citation:
        • Nutrition and cancer. Published August 2012.
  • Higher intake of legumes was associated with a decreased risk of several cancers including those of the upper aerodigestive tract, stomach, colorectum, and kidney, but not lung, breast, prostate or bladder. Further investigations of these associations in prospective cohort studies are warranted.
    • Link to article
    • Citation:
        • Cancer Causes & Control. Published 2009/11/01.
  • Our results suggest that adherence to a diet pattern rich in vegetables, fish, legumes and olive oil may favorably influence the risk of breast cancer. This study is the first investigation of dietary effects on breast cancer risk in Cyprus, a country whose population has traditionally adhered to the Mediterranean diet.
    • Link to article
    • Citation:
        • BMC Cancer. Published 2012.
  • Our results suggest that adherence to a diet pattern rich in vegetables, fish, legumes and olive oil may favorably influence the risk of breast cancer. This study is the first investigation of dietary effects on breast cancer risk in Cyprus, a country whose population has traditionally adhered to the Mediterranean diet.
    • Link to article
    • Citation:
        • BMC Cancer. Published 2012-03-23.
  • The tested fibre preparations do not affect lipid metabolism through bile acid-binding in normocholesterolaemic subjects. However, particularly blue lupin kernel fibre improve colonic function and have beneficial effects on putative risk factors for colorectal cancer such as faecal mass, transit time, SCFA, faecal pH, and secondary bile acid concentration. Therefore, enhancing dietary fibre intake through blue lupin up to about 50 g/d can be recommended.
    • Link to article
    • Citation:
        • Nutrition Journal. Published 2013.
  • Adherence to a Mediterranean dietary pattern did not decrease breast cancer risk in this cohort of relatively young women. Citation: Couto E, Sandin S, Löf M, Ursin G, Adami H-O, Weiderpass E (2013) Mediterranean Dietary Pattern and Risk of Breast Cancer.
